Award.AwardTitle: Integrated Dynamics of Temporal and Spatial Controls in the Cell Division of Caulobacter crescentus
Award.AbstractNarration:
The purpose of this project is to gain deeper insight into the molecular mechanisms controlling the growth, division and differentiation of bacteria by building mathematical models of gene expression and protein localization within a bacterial cell. The free-living aquatic bacterium, Caulobacter crescentus, is a suitable organism for addressing such questions because it divides asymmetrically into two different types of cells (a stalked cell and a swarmer cell) and because the molecular basis of its asymmetric division process is easily studied in the laboratory by modern genetic, biochemical and microscopic methods. In light of the wealth of experimental results now available on the genes and proteins controlling this process, the funded project will address the pressing need for accurate and predictive mathematical models that connect detailed molecular mechanisms with the observed properties of Caulobacter reproduction and differentiation. Two types of mathematical models will be considered. Deterministic models--based on systems of nonlinear partial differential equations--will be used to describe the average behavior of a population of Caulobacter cells, which is the type of data collected in many experimental protocols. Stochastic models--based on the reaction and diffusion of individual molecules within a single cell--will be used to describe the precise spatial distribution and temporal dynamics of specific proteins within cells, as measured by microscopic studies of fluorescently labeled proteins. This project will provide new ideas, methods, algorithms and software for spatiotemporal modeling of gene expression and protein dynamics in living cells. It will also provide training for two graduate students, a life scientist and a computer scientist, in modern methods of computational cell biology, mathematical modeling and spatial stochastic simulations.

The processes by which bacteria grow, divide and differentiate are of great importance to human welfare because we live in intimate relationships with many types of bacteria. Beneficial bacteria colonize our digestive tract, fix nitrogen for our crops, and produce valuable products in our bioreactors. Pathogenic bacteria cause diseases in us and in our crops and domestic animals. To gain control over both beneficial and pathogenic bacteria, we need to understand the molecular mechanisms governing bacterial reproduction and differentiation. Mathematical models are useful tools for exploring hypotheses about these mechanisms because they integrate a wealth of experimental evidence into a realistic and accurate computer representation of molecular interactions. Computer simulations then serve to test the hypotheses against known experimental facts in a comprehensive fashion and to predict the outcome of novel experimental studies. The cell division cycle of Caulobacter is a favorable case for testing the utility of mathematical modeling in molecular cell biology. In addition, because Caulobacter is closely related to both nitrogen-fixing and disease-causing bacteria and because its asymmetric mode of division is analogous to the reproduction and differentiation of human stem cells, the mathematical methods and biological results expected from this project may ultimately lead to practical developments in agriculture and medicine.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The free-living aquatic bacterium Caulobacter crescentus exhibits a dimorphic cell division cycle. Each division results in two morphologically distinct cells: a sessile stalked cell and a motile swarmer cell. The stalked cell remains anchored to a substrate, where it continues to grow, replicate its DNA and produce new swarmer cells. The swarmer cell swims off to find a new location of its own, where it differentiates into a stalked cell and completes the life cycle.

The underlying cause of Caulobacter's dimorphic division process is the asymmetric distributions of proteins to the two halves of the pre-divisional cell. Over the last decade, microscopists have identified 'landmark' proteins that localize to specific places along the cell body, especially to the poles. The spatial distributions of these proteins change during the course of the cell cycle. Currently, biologists are elucidating the molecular interactions that drive these spatiotemporal changes. The goal of this project was to construct detailed mathematical/computational models of the protein interaction network, to obtain a systems-level understanding of the control mechanism governing Caulobacter's dimorphic life cycle.

To build realistic models of these molecular processes is a challenging task mathematically because the genes, mRNAs and proteins move around within the cell and change their biochemical states in time as the cell grows and divides. In addition, all these processes take place in the tiny volume of a bacterial cell and involve small numbers of molecules (5-10 mRNA molecules and 500-5000 protein molecules per cell per gene). Hence, stochastic fluctuations in the numbers of these molecules (and, consequently, in their functions) are unavoidable. Not only must Caulobacter cells function reliably in the face of this "noise," but also mathematical models must accurately represent stochastic fluctuations in a spatiotemporally evolving system of biochemical reactions and mass transport.

The models have led to some surprising conclusions about the molecular control system in Caulobacter. (1) Translocation of the landmark protein, PopZ, to the "new pole" of the cell is the first step in the production of the swimming appendage (the flagellum) there. According to the model, proper localization of PopZ is a complex process involving movement of the newly replicated popZ gene to the new end of the cell (the end without the stalk), local transcription of a few mRNA molecules from this gene, production of freely diffusing PopZ monomers from these mRNAs, and self-activating polymerization of PopZ aggregates at the new end of the cell (inlfuenced by the curvature of the cell wall at the pole). (2) PleC is a bifunctional enzyme, serving as either a kinase or a phosphatase. By conventional wisdom, PleC functions primarily as a phosphatase, but the mathematical model supports an alternative view that PleC switches between phosphatase and kinase forms, and these switches are important for the differentiation of swarmer cells into stalked cells.

The project has led to some promising new methods for spatial stochastic modeling of reaction-diffusion systems: (1) Hybrid simulations, marrying discrete and continuous simulations in accurate and efficient ways. (2) Multi-scale simulations, dealing wit the fact that different types of molecules--genes, mRNAs and proteins--move around in cells at vastly different rates. (3) Reaction-propensity simulations, calculating the propensities of nonlinear reactions in the small volume elements used to discretize the spatial domain. Because the outcome of simulations can depend strongly on the methods used to do the calculations, it is essential that the numerical methods be carefully designed and tested for accuracy and reliability.
